newsitem.title: FRANCE: Alcatel says Matra bid would break up Thomson-CSF.
newsitem.headline: Alcatel says Matra bid would break up Thomson-CSF.

text.p: Alcatel Alsthom chairman Serge Tchuruk said on Tuesday that rival Lagardere's offer to buy the French state's 58 percent stake in Thomson-CSF would lead to a break-up of the defence electronics firm.

"(Lagardere defence unit) Matra will be forced to enter complex structures in which it will give up majority control to finance an operation which is beyond its means and which will inevitably lead to the break-up of Thomson-CSF," Tchuruk told a news conference.
Tchuruk said the Alcatel-Dassault joint offer would transfer activities from those two firms to Thomson-CSF and lead to 50 percent growth in the company's size.
Lagardere officials were not available for comment.
Dassault Industries chairman Serge Dassault said that a recent missiles alliance between Lagardere and Daimler-Benz Aerospace (DASA) was irrelevant to the Thomson-CSF privatisation.
"The fuss over of the DASA/Matra deal has nothing to do with the privatisation of Thomson-CSF. Our offer is serious," he said.
Commenting on newspaper remarks that a giant French defence grouping would scare other European defence companies, Dassault said "that's exactly the purpose".
